awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Transport Phenomena in Ultracold Neutral Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award supports a fundamental theoretical investigation of the transport properties of ultracold neutral plasmas. Ultracold plasmas are a novel state of matter because the low temperature causes constituent particles, electrons and ions, to be strongly coupled. This medium has fundamentally different properties than traditional plasmas, analogous to the ways in which liquids differ from gases. Strongly coupled plasmas arise in several disciplines influencing energy, security and fundamental physics research. Examples include dense plasmas found in inertial confinement fusion experiments, intense laser-material interaction studies, sonoluminescing microbubbles, as well as astrophysical objects such as white dwarfs and giant planet interiors. Ultracold plasmas provide a unique window to view this physics because they can be accurately measured using lasers. This enables detailed tests of theoretical models. In addition to the theoretical research, a complimentary outreach program will introduce the public to plasma physics through an interactive "What is Plasma" demonstration. This will be an integral part of a larger exhibit on the history of space science at the University of Iowa (UI) to be displayed by the UI Natural History Museum, and later as a traveling exhibit in the UI Mobile Museum.
 
Ultracold plasmas are formed by laser-induced ionization of trapped ultracold atoms, resulting in a charge-neutral mixture of cold ions and electrons. Advances provided by this project are statistical mechanical theory and molecular dynamics simulations capable of accounting for both components of the plasma. Theory and simulations in this relatively new field have focused on one-component models, treating the plasma as a single fluid. The new advances address two-component physics that will become increasingly important as experiments strive for lower temperatures. The particular processes that will be emphasized are equation of state, mutual diffusion, viscosity and energy relaxation rates. The project will focus on understanding how various microphysics processes affect macroscopic transport, including the opposite sign of electron and ion charge, the nonequilibrium nature of electrons and ions, and the dynamic dielectric response of the plasma. The results will provide insights into the fundamental physics of strongly coupled plasmas, contributing to several frontier research fields.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Plasmas are often a very hot and dilute state of matter - such as the surface of the Sun, or Earth's upper atmosphere. This is such a common circumstance that plasma theories take it as an assumption and are derived from a weak coupling expansion that is valid at such conditions. However, plasma can also exist in states that are too dense or cold to fit this description.  These strongly coupled plasmas are a novel form of matter that exists in an intermediate regime between the common dilute gas-like state, and a condensed matter state like a liquid or solid.  One such example is an ultracold neutral plasma, which is produced by ionizing a trapped ultracold atomic gas using a laser. Such plasmas provide an excellent means to study properties of strongly coupled plasmas because they can be produced on a table-top and can be sensitively measured using optical diagnostics.

 

The main results of this project were the development of a theoretical model that describes the rate of transfer of particles, momentum, and energy in strongly coupled plasmas, tests of this theory using first-principles molecular dynamics simulations, and the application of the theory to explore novel behaviors that may be observed in ultracold plasma experiments. One highlight was the prediction that strong coupling breaks a symmetry of traditional plasma theory. Specifically, as a result of the weak coupling expansion, traditional plasma theory predicts that the collision rate between two species in a plasma does not depend on the sign of their charges. For example, the collision rate would be predicted to be the same between ions and electrons as between ions and positrons. The theory predicted that this symmetry is broken at strong coupling conditions, where collisions between particles of opposite sign of charge (ions and electrons) significantly exceeds that between particles of the same sign of charge (ions and positrons). This prediction was tested using molecular dynamics simulations and motivates future experimental tests. It reveals a fundamental behavior associated with strong coupling that is expected to be exhibited in other systems, such as dense plasmas.

 

Broader Impacts: In parallel with the research, a substantial outreach project was performed that exposed thousands of students and members of the public to the fascinating properties of plasmas through a hands-on demonstration: The Iowa Planeterrella. This is a mechanical and electrical device that simulates how the solar wind plasma emitted from the Sun interacts with Earth and its magnetic field; simulating the aurora, radiation belts, and ring currents. It was built by graduate students over the first year of the project and was displayed by them at a number of outreach activities. These included a year-long museum exhibit on the history of space physics at the University of Iowa, housed in the flagship "Old Capitol Building", as well as three Plasma Expos at the annual American Physical Society Division of Plasma Physics meeting, the USA Science and Engineering Festival in Washington DC, and numerous classroom visits at the University of Iowa and in surrounding high schools. Participant feedback included statements that the exhibit was "inspiring" and "fun", motivating participants to further explore plasmas and its role in our lives.
